Robert E. "Bob" Simon, Jr. (April 10, 1914 – September 21, 2015)[1] was an American real estate entrepreneur, most known for founding the community of Reston, Virginia.[2][3][4] He was the maternal uncle of feminist historian and writer Elizabeth Fox-Genovese.[5]
 Simon was born in New York City in 1914,[6] the son of Robert Sr. and Elsa Weil Simon,[7] immigrants from Germany.[8][9] He was raised in Manhattan along with his four siblings.[7] He was of Jewish descent.[10]
 After graduating from Harvard University, Simon took over the family real estate management and development business. In 1961, with the proceeds from the sale of a family property, Carnegie Hall, Simon purchased 6,750 acres (27 km²) of land in Fairfax County, Virginia and hired Conklin + Rossant[11] to develop a master plan for the new town of Reston, Virginia, a planned community well known on the national level. (The town's name was derived from Simon's initials and the word "town".)[4][12]
Simon's new town concept emphasized quality of life for the individual and provided a community where people could live, work, and play without driving long distances.
 Simon returned to live in an apartment near Lake Anne in Reston in 1993[12] and helped celebrate Reston's 40th birthday in 2004.[13]
In that same year a bronze statue of Simon was placed on a park bench in Washington Plaza on Lake Anne, the original heart of the community he built.[4][13]
 A collection of Simon's donated materials is housed at the Specials Collections Research Center at the George Mason University Libraries.
 Simon married four times.[7] He was married to author and environmentalist Anne Wertheim Langman, daughter of Maurice Wertheim, and granddaughter of Henry Morgenthau Sr.[14] He was survived by his fourth wife (married 2004), Cheryl Terio-Simon; a daughter, Margo Prescott-Morris; and six stepchildren, Karen Terio, Betsy Langman Schulberg (married and divorced from Budd Schulberg), Deborah Langman Lesser, Lucinda Zilk, Tom Langman, and Adam Terio.[7][15][16]

Early life[edit]

Reston[edit]
After graduating from Harvard University, Simon took over the family real estate management and development business. In 1961, with the proceeds from the sale of a family property, Carnegie Hall, Simon purchased 6,750 acres (27 km²) of land in Fairfax County, Virginia and hired Conklin + Rossant[11] to develop a master plan for the new town of Reston, Virginia, a planned community well known on the national level. (The town's name was derived from Simon's initials and the word "town".)[4][12]
Simon's new town concept emphasized quality of life for the individual and provided a community where people could live, work, and play without driving long distances.
Simon returned to live in an apartment near Lake Anne in Reston in 1993[12] and helped celebrate Reston's 40th birthday in 2004.[13]
In that same year a bronze statue of Simon was placed on a park bench in Washington Plaza on Lake Anne, the original heart of the community he built.[4][13]

Personal life[edit]
Simon married four times.[7] He was married to author and environmentalist Anne Wertheim Langman, daughter of Maurice Wertheim, and granddaughter of Henry Morgenthau Sr.[14] He was survived by his fourth wife (married 2004), Cheryl Terio-Simon; a daughter, Margo Prescott-Morris; and six stepchildren, Karen Terio, Betsy Langman Schulberg (married and divorced from Budd Schulberg), Deborah Langman Lesser, Lucinda Zilk, Tom Langman, and Adam Terio.[7][15][16]
